pros: An excellent company culture with the ability to collaborate with GCB staff on all teams. Tuition reimbursement after 6 months and benefits package.
cons: The pay is good but could be better.

review_title: It can work for you if it’s your passion
pros: Flexible schedule Mileage reimbursement Holiday pay
cons: Clients can be difficult It can be stressful

job_title: Senior Care Manager in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Flexible schedule, rewarding career, holidays and weekends off
cons: Management (on a care manager level) is incompetent, HR is little to no help, quantity of work over quality of work, a lot of work after work hours, and the PTO policy is borderline unethical.

review_title: Best Nonprofit I've Ever Worked For
pros:
The CEO started part-time working 3rd shift so unlike many "suits" he actually understands what it's like to be working one-on-one with clients. He literally worked himself up through the ranks.
Compared to other organizations the benefits are good and although not guaranteed, ALL staff have received a yearly bonus while I've been there - that's UNHEARD of in the nonprofit sector.
And the people are awesome. I've read reviews that have been negative but I think unhappy people tend to be the loudest. Most of the supervisors and staff I've had the privilege to work with have been amazing. This work is not for everyone but if you want to make a difference in people's lives there is opportunity to grow at this organization. That is why SO many staff can boast of 5, 10, 20, and yes, OVER 30 years of working at the same place. If it was that bad I highly doubt we'd have those kind of numbers. If you are looking for a place that helps people and supports each other, I would encourage you to ignore the sour grapes and apply.
cons: It's like any job - the work we do is not for everyone. It's not super easy all the time. But if you like what you do and who you work with, the good days always outnumber the bad.

pros: PTO, flexibility, and helping clients
cons: Unqualified employees, negative work culture, pay, unrealistic expectations

pros: I Can't think of any
cons: Far too many to list

job_title: Medical Records Clerk in Cincinnati, OH

pros: GCB is an amazing organization. I love the staff, CEO, and the mission of the organization. There are so many opportunities for staff to move up and around. The pay and benefits are good. Most of leadership has been with the organization for 20+ years. The CEO, Jeff, is very down to Earth and friendly with all staff. I left due to another opportunity but I would totally consider rejoining the GCB in the future!
cons: All non-profits have to deal with budget and financing constraints. GCB is on top of how to utilize funding and billing to make sure staff are paid well.

job_title: Mental Health Case Manager in Amelia, OH
pros: A place where people who truly care for others work
cons: Good work at the ironic detriment of the worker's mental health

review_title: A Client Centered Approach to Behavioral Healthcare
pros: Greater Cincinnati Behavioral Health Services is laser focused on the health and well-being of their clients. Regardless of their position, every employee knows that the clients come first and they are willing to go the extra mile to ensure they receive the best care possible.
cons: We are always in need of people dedicated to serving our clients due to the needs of the workforce.

review_title: Meaningful work, overall decent benefits, exhausting
pros:
-Meaningful community work. Building great relationships with clients and building clinical skills. Opportunity to work with a diverse population
-Flexible schedule, willing to work with employees so they are able to go to school. Internship opportunities 
-A lot of opportunities for promotions if you have the necessary licensure. Very supportive of their employees getting Masters degrees
-Self-directed work and able to make your own schedule with clients
-Tuition reimbursement options
-PTO accumulates the longer you stay and never had any trouble getting time off work
-10 paid holidays a year
-Affordable yet quality health insurance
-Provided with an agency phone and laptop which helped with work-life balance when they are turned off at the end of the day
-Pay is good compared to similar roles at other agencies; having a license or masters degree expands your options. Yearly salary reviews and opportunities for bonuses depending on performance. Mental health care roles aren't the greatest paying jobs which is typical for the nation. GCB is on the right track in this area
cons:
-Very challenging work sometimes, especially if the caseloads are high
-High turnover in certain areas which made communication not great sometimes. Difficulty getting responses from HR during my final year of employment
-Use of personal car. A lot of wear and tear
-UR (productivity) seems to be everyone's biggest concern. You are still required to make up your productivity for taking time off, which means you have to work extra hard on the days you're working to be able to comfortably take a vacation and not get written up for your performance

pros: friendly staff, decent workload, fait enviroment
cons: only care about billing not treatment

pros: The coworkers are the only good part of this job.
cons: Micromanaging supervisors. This facility is filled with greed and all they care about is billing and collecting their check. I was encouraged to work overtime constantly to keep up with unrealistic expectations, was told I could get paid for it, never did. These people DO NOT care about their employees or the clients they are supposed to be helping. They take pride in how many clients they have (over 10,000) but once again, the more billing the more they get paid. This place is a disgrace of a company and drives their employees into the ground and tells them they are not working hard enough, good enough at their job, and constantly how they need to be able to 'manage themselves.' Meanwhile, all of my coworkers that I met feel the same way and are amazing people who want to help people in need!!!

pros: Wonderful clinical supervision and training opportunities. Ability to advance to higher positions. Management is very supportive and encourages your career goals.
cons: I do not have anything negative from my experience

pros: There are absolutely none, not one.
cons: Too many to even begin to list. Just run.

review_title: Awful place to work. If you have any creativity in your bones this is not the place to be
pros: It you love to be a sheep and a cookie cutter mold of a worker and agree with everything your team and supervisor says then this is the place for you.
cons:
You are in dangerous situations on a daily basis and if you voice that you are uncomfortable with a client, your safety is not number one; the client is. 
If you voice your opinion or a creative idea you will be shot down immediately and even possibly written up for disrespect of your superiors. 
You are expected to do more than you humanly are capable of and if you are unable to accomplish such, you will be reprimanded and as a result your job becomes harder. 
The whole GCB is top employer thing is definitely a lie and I am pretty sure the people rating on here are the very few who love their job.

review_title: AVOID THIS PLACE LIKE THE PLAGUE!
job_title: Case Manager in Clermont County, OH
pros: The ONLY positive is your amazing co-workers. That's it!
cons:
Everything else. You WILL quit in 6 months or less, nearly everybody does. In that period, you'll be treated terribly by inept and unethical management. You'll be forced to look at your clients as merely numbers on a page. When you can't make productivity (I did), your managers will not help, because they are hapless. 

Vacation? Yep, take it and then be threatened, because you didn't make productivity. 

Pay? Awful, and your incentive can change without any notice. 

This is the biggest con in mental health, with the employees and clients taking the brunt. Because...well...they don't care about there employees and they sure don't care about their clients.

"Top 10 workplace?" Yep...look into that shady quid pro quo. 

Go ahead and apply, but you can't say I didn't warn you. This place is a graveyard for early-career mental health professionals!

pros: GCB is a great place to work, they are flexible and you get bonuses for your productivity - you will find that you are truly able to change people's lives through your work at GCB.  You will meet amazing people, staff and clients alike
cons: The challenges to working at GCB do not have to do with the company as much as the lack of resources available to help your clients -  the economy has affected not just big companies but affected non profit and community agencies as well, if not more so -  the other challenge.....bed bugs, be aware and take measures and you will be fine

pros: You do get reimbursed well for travel, there are opportunities for bonuses, and working on-call hours can boost your take-home pay.
cons: Extremely draining mentally and emotionally, you're expected to transport clients in your personal vehicle and sometimes give out your personal phone number, there isn't a whole lot of support from the agency when you're feeling burnt out, and the productivity can sometimes be too demanding.

pros:
It's a good work environment. 
You can make your own schedule. 
You get to really interact with clients and feel you are making a difference.
cons:
It felt a little unsafe having to go through 2 locked doors to get to my office. 
High turnover with the case management teams. 
Not the greatest location to work.

job_title: Mental Health Care Manager in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Flexible schedule (get your productivity hours in and you can make your scheduled however you would like), no micromanaging (again, keep up with your hours and paperwork and no one interferes or asks questions), mileage and cell phone reimbursement
cons: Support not very apparent, if you get behind, no one really helps you (including your supervisor), high caseloads

review_title: Would give 0 stars if I could
pros: They reimburse you a few dollars a month for your phone
cons: The supervisors are on relatable and unapproachable. HR is the absolute worst, they couldn’t care less about you or anything about the case managers job. If you do have productivity that probably means that you are working from the time you get up until the time you go to bed every day and all weekend to complete your notes for how much you actually have to work. This is not a 40 hour a week job this is a 70+ Hours a week job

review_title: My experience has been productive and effective
pros: On-call; mileage reimbursement; cell phone reimbursement; great morale and it is like a one stop shop for clients; great supervisors
cons: Productivity; mileage time consuming; not enough computers to submit CPST notes; hourly pay should be higher those at other agencies or position make more without having a degree.

pros: Nothing. Possibly flexibility. You had to lie about where you were but you could do things and no one knew. As soon as you asked to do an 8am doctor appt you go in trouble though.
cons:
Being employed there. I worked 12 or more hours a day. I couldn't spend time with my family or I would get farther behind. As long as you were getting billable hours they didn't care. If you were handling a difficult case and got behind even though it was well documented what the issue was. They offered a lot of paid time off. Good luck using it. You are still responsible for all the billable hours you missed. Take 5 days off to go on vacation with your family? You'll be working unpaid overtime for the entire quarter to get that time off. They can also deny your vacation even last minute if you aren't where you are supposed to be. I had murders and sex offenders that I had to visit with in their homes regularly by myself. Turn on the news...those neighborhoods where the gun violence is.. you will be ALONE in those areas most of your time working. Insurance is horrible!! Pay is below average from what I've read on sources like glassdoor. You will tear up your car and if you get stuck in the community with a flat tire or something like that you will be forced to take PTO hours while it is getting fixed and no one comes to help you. There is no support from management. People have been fired for suggesting change although they would deny it. They also teach you how to commit welfare fraud and then threaten you with being fired but also push for you to do those things. Driving a client and billing insurance is not allowed. But as a care Manager you will be taught how to word it so that you can still do it. FRAUD.  When capable people apply for SSA benefits you are not supposed to say anything that can keep them from getting it. Even if you know specifically that they can work and are doing under the table work.  Also...if hired...you may not make it through the training. They let people go in training despite not telling them it was possible. Last thing. There is little to no opportunity for advancement in this agency. You have very little opportunity if you are licensed in social work. If you have any other degree you have 0 opportunity to advance or grow. 

I know this will not keep everyone from applying but if it helps save ONE  other person from going through this madness it was well worth the time to write this.

review_title: For your mental health, I’d advise you to just not
pros: I met some amazing team members and I do love seeing clients succeed
cons:
The cons of this job far outweigh the pros. 1st) There are care managers in Amelia selling their mlm items to clients. These clients get upset when different care managers couldn’t provide while care manager was on maternity leave. Supervisors did nothing to alleviate the problem or take action against illegal actions by care managers.

2nd) You get paid salary with no overtime benefits, but you’ll work overtime every week. You can’t take your PTO because it will require you to work overtime another day to make up for it. Productivity is 4.25 hours a day, but during a pandemic and half the people don’t want to engage or respond and there is little support to navigate.

3rd) GCB is suppose to help clients employ numerous skills to being productive members of society. Imagine teaching others about kindness and grace when being overwhelmed and stressed but when GCB was staring into the unknown of the pandemic, they failed to use grace. They furloughed employees via email in the middle of a Wednesday. To make matters worse, they sent another email shortly after forgetting to remove those that were furloughed, telling the company that furloughs took place and if you didn’t get the email you were safe. Then to discuss the stress from overwhelming client caseloads, they introduce yoga. However, yoga couldn’t be used as a work time activity but they only offered it in the morning, on Wednesday, before team meetings, during the normal working hours. It was the first time I realized that employees are nothing but a number. If GCB valued their employees they would have used grace and then accepted accountability for their poor taste in handling furloughs. 

4) the turnover time is outrageous right now. Many teams are experiencing employees quitting leaving vulnerable people waiting and feeling lost. GCB is not approaching that gap with kindness or grace. They are just expecting their workers to saddle more clients.

pros:
The only pro of this job would be the flexibility of making your own hours, but you are really at the mercy of your clients 

You can get a nice bonus if you go over your required productivity hours, but it comes at a high price of over exerting yourself.
cons:
Productivity: Productivity is a great concept to keep employees from being lazy and not doing work, but the way GCB does it should be illegal. You are expected to meet a certain number of hours each quarter, and you have the entire quarter to get those hours. BUT, if you decide to use some of your hard earned PTO, those days are not taken out of your productivity reports, so you are still expected to make up those hours you missed, even though you earned those days off. It's basically theft from the company and you are forced to work overtime the rest of the quarter if you don't want to be penalized. 

Safety: You are put in unsafe situations A LOT. There are times when you meet a client for the very first time, they have a dangerous background and you have to go on your own to their home to meet with them to satisfy the requirements. You have absolutely no idea what you are walking into.

Not good use of degree: Half of your caseload will be clients that are somewhat reliable and have no problem meeting with you, the other half is hard to engage and you have to go out of your way to try and meet with them. There is a very high caseload, so if half is very needy, you spend the majority of your time dealing with them and you have zero time to reach out to the unengaged clients that need the most help. I felt like most of my days were spent at the grocery store with clients walking around,  and then carrying all of their groceries to their top floor apartment due to physical concerns, NOT mental concerns. I felt more like an aid/personal taxi driver than a mental health case worker. You shouldn't be expected to do tasks like that, and they encourage it because spending that time with clients is a way for the company to get billable hours and profit off of clients. I've had my supervisor call me and tell me a client has been tattling on me for not taking them shopping at walmart and I need to call them and set up a time to go, even though they are capable of taking the bus.

No support; The supervisors are busy too, and because of this you get very little help or support from them. Some teams have a lot of unison, and others do not. GCB won't even help you if a client breaks/destroys part of your car. 

Burnout: You get burnt out very quickly. It was nice to be able to go home early some days and work from home. But I was often so mentally exhausted I couldn't get off my couch to run my own errands since you are driving clients around all day running their errands. And you STILL have clients blowing up your phone when the day is over. I found myself doing notes late at night or on the weekends just because I was too tired to do them during "work hours". You can work over 40 hours a week and not meet productivity.

pros: Rewarding helping others with challenges; the people I worked with were good colleagues as well; the hours are often flexible
